abstract.text: A configuration object that contains the traits that the system uses when selecting the current image variant.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Images may contain multiple variants to account for environmental factors, such as whether the interface is light or dark. The image configuration object lets you override the current environment and render an image with specific attributes. For example, you might want to render a specific version of your image to your interface.
objects are immutable and you don’t create them directly. Instead, get an existing image configuration object from a
object. To add attributes to your configuration object, use the
method to create a new object that merges the existing object’s values with new values you supply. Assign the new object to the
object you use to display the image. If you draw the image directly, use the
method to create a new image that contains the new attributes.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An object that manages image data in your app.
A configuration object that contains the traits that the system uses when selecting the current image variant.
Returns a configuration object that applies the specified configuration values on top of the current object’s values.
The traits associated with the image configuration.
Returns a new configuration object that merges the current traits with the traits from the specified trait collection.
An object that contains the specific font, size, style, and weight attributes to apply to a symbol image.
Returns a new version of the current image, replacing the current configuration attributes with the specified attributes.
A view that displays a single image or a sequence of animated images in your interface.
The configuration values to use when rendering the image.
A collection of data that represents the environment for an individual element in your app’s user interface.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
